context: During the different treatments, neither elemental sulphur nor peaks associated to other sulphur compounds were detected. This is explained either by the possible formation of soluble non-volatile sulphur compounds which would not be transferred to the headspace and/or the low concentration of the generated sulphur compounds which could be below the detection limits of GC/PFPD as well as the IC. In the case of UV/H2O2 and Fenton treatments, the mineralisation degrees (54% and 58% respectively) were similar despite having different hydrogen peroxide consumptions (43% and 72%). This fact is explained by the competition for hydroxyl radial between Fe2+ and organic sulphur compounds in solution, leading to the non-productive decomposition of hydrogen peroxide and thereby consuming more amount of it (Neyens and Baeyens, 2003). On the other hand, during the different AOPs the pHs were reduced among 0.2–0.5 pH units at the end of the reaction. This could be caused mainly by the generation of SO4 2 − or the formation of short chain organic acids. Ma et al. (2013) detected the formation of acetic acid during the first stages of the oxidation of ETM with hydroxyl radicals.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, hydrogen peroxide is involved in advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) where it competes with organic sulfur compounds for hydroxyl radicals during treatments like UV/H2O2 and Fenton. The presence of organic sulfur compounds affects the efficiency of hydrogen peroxide decomposition, leading to increased consumption of hydrogen peroxide without significant mineralization of sulfur compounds. This indicates a competitive relationship where organic sulfur compounds influence the reactivity and effectiveness of hydrogen peroxide in the treatment process.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 4 reflects a significant connection between hydrogen peroxide and organic sulfur compounds, as their interaction is crucial in determining the efficiency of advanced oxidation processes. The context provides evidence of competition for hydroxyl radicals, highlighting their interdependence in the treatment mechanisms.
